Dirty Dan Reviews Music: "Work" by Rihanna

By Dirty "Dirty Dan" Dan

Song: Work
Artist: Rihanna (ft. Drake)
Label: Westbury Road / Roc Nation

Work, the recent product of a Drake/Rihanna collaboration, is the embodiment of what can only be called a revolution in todayâ€™s music industry. The first thing you notice about Work is the exquisite drum machine beat, allegedly influenced by Jamaican dancehall music, popular in the 80s and 90s. The precisely placed artificial hand claps and kick drums generate a laid back but intense groove that harkens back to the golden years of dancehall. The intricate â€œğŸ”¥fireâ€ beat ğŸµ was created by producer Rupert â€œSevnâ€ Thomas in Drakeâ€™s house in L.A., which was described as a â€œbeat ğŸµ factoryâ€ by Thomas himself. This perfectly represents Rihannaâ€™s work, which is characterized by an assembly line constructed, mass produced nature that perfectly befits itself for the masses.

Though this description may sound impressive, in reality it undersells the true genius behind the ğŸ”¥fire beats ğŸµ which pervade Drake and Rihannaâ€™s music. Picking which sounds and buttons to press on a computer to program an artificial drum beat ğŸµ takes many minds to put together and is no easy task. In fact, it would be fair to say that â€œSevnâ€ Thomas could be considered the â€œJimi Hendrix of the MacBook Proâ€. Let us not forget the Seven (Sevn?) other talents that collaborated on this song by pressing buttons - PartyNextDoor, Allen Ritter, Rupert â€œSevnâ€ Thomas, Monte Moir, R. Stephenson, and Boi-1da, as well as Rihanna and Drake received songwriting (song manufacturing?) credits for Work.

The true genius behind Work, however, is the two accompanying music videos. Previously the song had been merely a musical masterpiece with ğŸ”¥fire beats ğŸµ and autotuned mumbling by a simultaneously bollywood-esque hand-dancing Drake. However, the two videos, one featuring a twerk-fest in a marijuana-haze filled Jamaican club, and the other featuring a couch being sat on by Drake and a Rihannaâ€™s behind being gazed at by Drake, truly elevate the song to the level of fine art. One can almost feel the emotional pain of Rihanna as she belts out her lovesick poetry, (â€œHow many more shots until youâ€™re rolling?â€) and the physical pain of Drakeâ€™s crotch as it is grinded (ground?) to shreds by Rihannaâ€™s butt. After the song is over, we can only reflect on the emotional impact of the symphony (one can almost refer to it as if it is classical music, an instant timeless classic) and we are left mulling over the philosophical, genius, flowing poetry of its lyrics - â€œYou see me I be work, work, work, work, work, workâ€¦Duh, duh, duh, nana nana nana.â€
